punct, number fmt
revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Location map+ |Jordan |width=200 |float=right |caption=Water will be pumped from the Disi aquifer to [[Amman]], [[Jordan]]. |places= {{Location map~ |Jordan |lat=29.3|long=35.5 |label=Disi aquifer|marksize = 12}} {{Location map~ |Jordan |lat=31.93658 |long=35.94570 |label=[[Amman]]|marksize = 12}} }} The '''Disi Water Conveyance Project''' is a [[water supply]] project in [[Jordan]]. It is designed to pump {{convert|100,000,000|m3|impgal|lk=on}} of [[water]] per year from the Disi [[aquifer]],<ref name="ieee "/> which lies beneath the desert in southern [[Jordan]] and northwestern [[Saudi Arabia]]. The water is piped to the capital, [[Amman]], and other cities to meet increased demand. Construction began in 2009 and was mostly completed in July 2013 when the project was inaugurated by King Abdullah of Jordan.<ref name=Inauguration/> Its total cost was US$1.1 billion.
An independent study revealed the water to be [[radioactive]] and potentially dangerous to drink, initially surrounding the project with controversy.<ref name=ieee>{{cite news |last=Upson |first=Sandra |title=Jordan's radioactive water problem |url=http://spectrum.ieee.org/energy/environment/jordans-radioactive-water-problem/3 |accessdate=22 February 2011 |newspaper=Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) Spectrum |date=August 2009}}</ref><ref name=esc>{{cite journal |last=Vengosh |first=Avner |last2=Hirschfeld |first2=Daniella |last3=Vinson |first3=David |last4=Dwyer |first4=Gary |last5=Raanan |first5=Hadas |last6=Rimawi |first6=Omar |last7=Al-Zoubi |first7=Abdallah |last8=Akkawi |first8=Emad |last9=Marie |first9=Amer |last10=Haquin |first10=Gustavo |last11=Zaarur |first11=Shikma |last12=Ganor |first12=Jiwchar |display-authors=3 |title=High Naturally Occurring Radioactivity in Fossil Groundwater from the Middle East |journal=Environmental Science & Technology |date=15 March 2009 |volume=43 |issue=6 |pages=1769–75 |doi=10.1021/es802969r |url=http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/es802969r}}</ref> Jordan's Ministry of Water and Irrigation has stated that the radioactivity is not a problem because the water is to be diluted with an equal amount of water from other sources, although it remains disputed if this would be enough to bring the water up to standards.<ref name=ieee/> The Ministry said the independent study was inaccurate, as it did not test water from any of the wells that will be used in the project.<ref name=jt3>{{cite news |last=Namrouqa |first=Hana |title=Disi project will go ahead despite radiation allegations |url=http://www.jordantimes.com/?news=14733 |accessdate=23 February 2011 |newspaper=Jordan Times |date=3 March 2009}}</ref> The President of the Jordanian Geologists Association Bahjat Al Adwan stated that the radiation is present in the water in the form of [[Radon]], and thus dissipates harmlessly when the water is exposed to air on the surface.<ref name=JT5>{{cite news |last=Numan |first=Abeer |title=Disi water uncontaminated |url=http://www.jordantimes.com/index.php?news=37584 |accessdate=30 May 2011 |newspaper=The Jordan Times |date=18 May 2011}}</ref>
==Background== [[File:Aqaba3.jpg|thumb|left|150px|The Disi aquifer currently supplies [[Aqaba]] with 15 million cubic meters of water per year.]] The water in the Disi aquifer gathered 30,000 years ago during the [[Pleistocene era]]. It is {{convert|320|km|mi}} long and located {{convert|500|m|ft}} below ground inside of porous [[sandstone]].<ref name="Allen">{{cite journal |url=http://www.ce.utexas.edu/prof/mckinney/ce397/Topics/Groundwater/Groundwater_Disi(2010).pdf |title=Disi Aquifer: Jordan and Saudi Arabia |last=Allen |first=John |journal=Transboundary Water Resource |date=May 2010 |accessdate=22 February 2011}}</ref> The aquifer is classified as a [[fossil water|fossil aquifer]], meaning that the water is not [[Groundwater recharge|replenished]] if it is removed. In fact, the aquifer has a recharge rate of {{convert|50,000,000|m3|impgal|abbr=on}} of water per year. This recharge is dwarfed, however, by the current extraction rate of {{convert|90,000,000|m3|impgal|abbr=on}} for agricultural and domestic needs, including {{convert|15,000,000|m3|impgal|abbr=on}} of water that is supplied to [[Aqaba, Jordan]].<ref name=boell>Page 68: {{cite journal |last=Wardam |first=Batir |title=More politics then water: Water rights in Jordan |journal=Global Issue Papers |date=September 2004 |issue=11 |url=http://www.boell.de/downloads/internationalepolitik/GIP11_Jordan_Batir_Wardam.pdf |accessdate=22 February 2011 |publisher=Heinrich Böll Foundation |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718191500/http://www.boell.de/downloads/internationalepolitik/GIP11_Jordan_Batir_Wardam.pdf |archivedate=18 July 2011 |df= }}</ref> The current extraction rate of {{convert|90,000,000|m3|impgal|abbr=on}}, coupled with the future extraction rate of {{convert|100,000,000|m3|impgal|abbr=on}} for the project,<ref name="ieee"/> is expected to produce a total extraction rate of {{convert|190,000,000|m3|impgal|abbr=on}}. At that rate, the water in the aquifer will last a minimum of 50 years, according to the Disi Water Company.<ref name="zawya">{{cite news|last=Namrouqa |first=Hana |title=After Disi setbacks, GAMA playing 'catch up' |url=http://www.zawya.com/Story.cfm/sidZAWYA20110214044445/After%20Disi%20setbacks,%20GAMA%20playing%20'catch%20up |accessdate=23 February 2011 |newspaper=[[The Jordan Times]] |date=14 Feb 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140411011225/http://www.zawya.com/story/ZAWYA20110214044445/ |archivedate=April 11, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
Only a small portion of the Disi aquifer lies beneath [[Jordan]], while the majority lies beneath [[Saudi Arabia]]. Saudi Arabia also extracts water from the aquifer (called the Saq aquifer in Saudi Arabia).<ref name="Natgeo">{{cite news |url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2010/05/100505-fossil-water-radioactive-science-environment/ |title=Underground "Fossil Water" Running Out |accessdate=March 15, 2011 |last=Handwerk |first=Brian |date=6 May 2010 |newspaper=National Geographic News}}</ref> The aquifer has created controversy between Saudi Arabia and Jordan, with each country demanding the other to use less of the shared water. There is no formal agreement between the countries regarding the water and the Disi Water Conveyance Project is being constructed without Saudi consultation or involvement.<ref name=Allen/>
[[Non-revenue water]] is a serious problem in Amman. Currently, 40% of water in Amman is lost as non-revenue water. The city rations water, with individual residents averaging 36 hours of water access weekly. If the non-revenue water problem remains, it is possible that a large portion of the water provided by the Disi Water Conveyance project will also be lost as it is piped through Amman.<ref name="gwi">{{cite journal |url=http://www.globalwaterintel.com/archive/10/6/general/amman-looks-to-boost-supply-and-plug-the-leaks.html |title=Amman looks to boost supply and plug the leaks |journal=Global Water Intelligence |date=June 2009 |volume=10 |issue=6}}</ref>
The Disi Water Conveyance project was first proposed in the 1990s, but was initially regarded as too expensive. A feasibility study was completed in 1996.<ref name=Sweco>{{cite web |title=Water and wastewater projects in Jordan |url=http://www.swecogroup.com/en/Sweco-group/Solutions/Water-and-environment/Water-and-Wastewater/Water-and-wastewater-projects-in-Jordan1/ |publisher=Sweco |accessdate=25 March 2014}}</ref> But it was not until 2007 that the Jordanian Government was able to contract a firm to begin construction.<ref name=executive>{{cite news |title=Jordan - Water from a desert well |url=http://www.executive-magazine.com/getarticle.php?article=12040 |accessdate=6 April 2011 |newspaper=Executive |date=July 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719161316/http://www.executive-magazine.com/getarticle.php?article=12040 |archivedate=19 July 2011 |df= }}</ref>
==Design== [[File:Amman.jpg|thumb|The water will be used to meet growing demand from Jordan's capital, [[Amman]].]] The project proposed by the Jordanian government will pump {{convert|100,000,000|m3|impgal|abbr=on}} of water per year from 55 [[Water well|wells]] in the aquifer.<ref name=ieee/><ref name=zawya/><ref name=jt>{{cite news |last=Namrouqa |first=Hana |title=Disi project construction in full force |url=http://www.jordantimes.com/index.php?news=29050 |accessdate=23 February 2011 |newspaper=The Jordan Times |date=10 August 2010}}</ref> However, a total of 64 wells will be drilled, the extra wells to be used as [[piezometers]] to measure the elevation of the water.<ref name=zawya/> Nine of the 55 water producing wells will be used in emergencies only. The wells producing water will be drilled {{convert|600|-|700|m|ft|abbr=on}} deep while the piezometers will be drilled to a depth of {{convert|400|m|ft|abbr=on}}.<ref name=zawya/> The plan is to pump the piezometer wells for 25 years, according to the project leader.<ref name="ieee"/>
After being pumped from the wells, water will then be transported to [[Amman]], via a {{convert|325|km|mi|abbr=on}} pipeline, passing through a pumping station, then flowing by gravity and being pumped up again. The reservoirs near Amman are only {{convert|200|m|ft|abbr=on}} higher than the surface area where the pumping field is located. Nevertheless, the total elevation differential over which water needs to be lifted by both pumping stations is about {{convert|800|m|ft}}.<ref name="cc">{{cite web |url=http://www.ccjo.com/Projects/Environment/DISIMUDAWWARATOAMMANWATERCONVEYANCESYSTEM/tabid/559/Default.aspx |title=Disi-Mudawwara Amman Water Conveyance System - Jordan |accessdate=April 5, 2011 |publisher=Consolidated Consultants}}</ref> To pump the water through the proposed pipeline will require 4 kilowatt-hours per cubic meter of water. The entire project would require approximately 4 percent of Jordan's current electrical production. The project is expected to be completed by January 2017 and to run for 25 years or until the [[Two Seas Canal]] is built.<ref name=ieee/>
The {{convert|100,000,000|m3|impgal|abbr=on}} of water will be divided between the Abu Alanda reservoir and the Dabouq reservoir. Approximately {{convert|40,000,000|m3|impgal|abbr=on}} of water will be sent to the Abu Alanda reservoir where it will be diluted with water from the Zara Ma’en desalination plant as well as water from Wala. The remaining {{convert|60,000,000|m3|impgal|abbr=on}} of water will be sent to the Dabouq reservoir where it will be diluted with water from the Zai Treatment Plant as well as water from Wala.<ref name=ieee/> It is estimated that the cost of one cubic meter of water from the project will be 0.74 [[Jordanian dinar|JOD]] (US$1.05).<ref name =jt/>
==Construction== In June 2009, the Turkish firm [[GAMA Endustri|GAMA]] began construction.<ref>{{cite news |title=Disi project to finish ahead of schedule |last=Namrouqa |first=Hana |url=http://www.jordantimes.com/index.php?news=18393<!-- |url2=http://www.zawya.com/marketing.cfm?zp&p=/Story.cfm/sidZAWYA20090714032649--> |accessdate=7 April 2011 |newspaper=The Jordan Times |date=14 July 2009}}</ref> By February 2011, eight piezometer wells and two water producing wells have been completed. Twenty-three other wells were to be drilled, and {{convert|85|km|mi|abbr=on}} of pipe were to be installed.<ref name=zawya/> By April 2011, 99% of the {{convert|340|km|mi|abbr=on}} of project's piping had arrived from Turkey, an anonymous source told ''[[The Jordan Times]]''. This source stated that the project was over 50% completed and that it was ahead of schedule.<ref name=zawya2>{{cite news |last=Namrouqa |first=Hana |title='50% of Disi project completed' |url=http://www.jordantimes.com/index.php?news=36599&searchFor=Disi%20Project<!-- |url2=http://www.zawya.com/story.cfm/sidZAWYA20110417042730--> |accessdate=17 April 2011 |newspaper=The Jordan Times |date=17 April 2011}}</ref> [[File:Beduinphoto.jpg|thumb|A traditional [[Bedouin]] man in Southern Jordan]]
Construction was delayed by disgruntled members of a [[Bedouin|Bedouin tribe]] living in the area, who allegedly intimidated workers by shooting in the air and at construction equipment. All work was stopped for two weeks after two employees were killed in January 2011 — allegedly murdered by a member of the Bedouin tribe.<ref name=jt2>{{cite news |last=Namrouqa |first=Hana |title=Safety concerns 'hindering progress' in Disi water project |url=http://www.jordantimes.com/?news=34480 |accessdate=23 February 2011 |newspaper=[[The Jordan Times]] |date=14 February 2011}}</ref><ref name="jt5">{{cite news |url=http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?did=2229462861&sid=1&Fmt=3&clientId=28955&RQT=309&VName=PQD |title=Government warns rioters in southern Jordanian town |accessdate=March 16, 2011 |date=5 January 2011 |newspaper=The Jordan Times}}</ref> The tribe had been upset because GAMA did not rent its water tankers, according to Adnan Zu'b, Assistant Secretary Genera at the Ministry of Water and Irrigation. To satisfy the tribe, GAMA then announced plans to rent tankers from the tribe.<ref name=jt2/> However, near the site of the killings, the town of [[Ma'an]] had protests against the government's failure to punish the killers.<ref name=jt5/> During October and November, 2011 the construction works have been suspended at southern part of the project from Hasa to [[Mudawwara]] due to security problems created by tribes, therefore there is delay in this part which will affect the completion date of the project.
==Structure and funding== The project is funded on a [[build-operate-transfer]] concession contract between the Jordanian government and the Disi Water Company (Diwaco), a subsidiary of the Turkish construction company [[GAMA Enerji|GAMA Energy]]. GAMA Energy is a joint venture between the Turkish GAMA Holding and the US firm [[General Electric]] Energy Financial Services.<ref>General Electric: [http://www.genewscenter.com/content/detailEmail.aspx?ReleaseID=7280&NewsAreaID=2&changeCurrentLocale=5 GAMA, GE To Bring Water to Northern Jordan Through Investment In US$1 Billion Pipeline], 8 July 2009</ref> Diwaco is responsible to build the project over a 4-year period and to operate it for another 25 years. At the end of the concession period the ownership will transfer to the Jordanian government.<ref name=ume>{{cite news |last=Attwood |first=Edward |title=US $1bn water project to bring hope to Jordan |url=http://www.utilities-me.com/article-56-us_1bn_water_project_to_bring_hope_to_jordan/ |accessdate=23 February 2011 |newspaper=Utilities Middle East |date=14 July 2009}}</ref> Diwaco will retain any profits and will bear the risk of losing its equity. Construction is undertaken by GAMA Power Systems, another subsidiary of GAMA Holding, under a turnkey engineering, procurement and construction contract with Diwaco. Operation will be undertaken by Disi Amman Operation Maintenance LLC, a fully owned subsidiary of the French water company [[Suez Environnement]], under a separate operating contract with Diwaco.<ref name="tradearabia">{{cite news |url=http://tradearabia.com/news/CONS_164108.html |title=$1bn Jordan water project set to start |accessdate=March 18, 2011 |date=8 July 2009 |publisher=TradeArabia}}</ref>
The project is funded through an equity contribution of about US$200M from Diwaco, a $300M grant and a $100M stand-by facility from the Jordanian government, as well as US$475M in foreign loans to Diwaco.<ref name =jt/><ref name="jt4">{{cite news |url=http://www.jordantimes.com/?news=22039 |title=Disi project construction work officially begins |accessdate=March 15, 2011 |date=3 December 2009 |newspaper=The Jordan Times}}</ref> The project's total cost is expected to be US$1.1 billion.<ref name =jt/> The U.S. [[Overseas Private Investment Corporation]] has lent US$250M to Diwaco to support U.S. foreign investment on the basis that General Electric partially owns GAMA Energy.<ref name="opic">{{cite web |url=http://www.opic.gov/node/2319 |title=Disi Water PSC |accessdate=March 17, 2011 |publisher=Overseas Private Investment Corporation |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721060643/http://www.opic.gov/node/2319 |archivedate=July 21, 2011 |df= }}</ref> The state-owned French bank [[PROPARCO]], which is the part of the [[French Development Agency]] (AFD) that supports private sector development, and the [[European Investment Bank]] (EIB) each lent about US$100M to Diwaco. The loan package has been put together by the [[Arab Banking Corporation]].<ref name="abc">{{cite web |url=http://www.arabbanking.com/En/AboutABC/Media/Press/Pages/ABCclosesUS$475millionfacilityforDIWACO.aspx |title=ABC closes US$475 million multi-tranche loan facilities for Jordan’s Disi Water Company (DIWACO) |accessdate=March 17, 2011 |publisher=Arab Banking Corporation}}</ref> Much of the government grant supporting the project comes from sovereign [[soft loan]]s that the government of Jordan has borrowed from the EIB and AFD and passes on as a grant to the project.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.jordantimes.com/?news=16269 |title=Disi project financial closure expected to be finalised this week |accessdate=March 15, 2011 |last=Namrouqa |first=Hana |date=29 April 2009 |newspaper=The Jordan Times}}</ref><ref name="ooska">{{cite news |url=http://www.ooskanews.com/middle-east-africa/disi-project-designs-finalized |title=Disi Project Designs Finalized |accessdate=March 15, 2011 |date=22 February 2010 |publisher=Ooska News}}</ref><ref name="eib">{{cite web |url=http://www.eib.org/projects/loans/2008/20080462.htm |title=South North Water Conveyor |accessdate=March 17, 2011 |publisher=European Investment Bank}}</ref> AFD provided US$50M for the state grant and $48M for the stand-by facility.<ref name="nlevd">{{cite web |url=http://www.evd.nl/zoeken/showbouwsteen.asp?bstnum=259961&location=&highlight= |title=Disi-Mudawarra to Amman water conveyance system |accessdate=March 17, 2011 |publisher=NL EVD International: |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130222142241/http://www.evd.nl/zoeken/showbouwsteen.asp?bstnum=259961&location=&highlight= |archivedate=February 22, 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref name="undp">{{cite web |url=http://www.climatefinanceoptions.org/cfo/node/212 |title=EIB North-South Water Conveyor (Jordan) |accessdate=March 18, 2011 |publisher=UNDP/World Bank Climate Finance Options |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130414114312/http://www.climatefinanceoptions.org/cfo/node/212 |archivedate=April 14, 2013 |df= }}</ref>
==Radioactivity concerns== The project became controversial in 2009 when a study performed by Avner Vengosh of [[Duke University]] revealed the Disi water to be highly [[radioactive]]. Water was tested from 37 existing wells in the aquifer, and all but one had concentrations of radioactive [[radium-226]] and [[radium-228]] isotopes that exceeded [[Drinking water#Regulation|international standards for drinking water]].<ref name=ieee/> Some of the water tested exceeded standards by 2,000%.<ref name=esc/> Drinking water with these isotopes has been linked to [[bone cancer]] and [[leukemia]].<ref name=bg>{{cite news |last=Vinocur |first=Nick |title=Excess radiation found in ancient Jordan wells |url=http://www.boston.com/news/world/europe/articles/2009/02/26/excess_radiation_found_in_ancient_jordan_wells/ |accessdate=23 February 2011 |newspaper=Boston Globe |date=26 February 2009}}</ref> Though expensive, the water could be purified of the radioactive isotopes through [[Ion-exchange resin#Water purification|ion-exchange purification]].<ref name=ieee/>
Jordan's Ministry of Water and Irrigation has stated that the radioactivity is not a problem because the water is to be diluted with an equal amount of water from other sources. This dilution would presumably halve the radioactivity of the water which, according to Vengosh's data, would not be enough to bring the water up to standards.<ref name=ieee/> The Ministry of Water and Irrigation, however, has declared Vengosh's data to be inaccurate, as his study did not test water from any of the wells that will be used in the project. As radiation varies from well to well, it is possible that the data Vengosh collected does not accurately reflect the water sources to be used in the project.<ref name=jt3/>
Although testing at the [[Water well|well sites]] that supply Aqaba reveals high radioactivity, testing performed using water from the tap in Aqaba shows the water to be safe. There is no confirmed explanation for this phenomenon, although it is hypothesized that the depth of the wells (the ones that supply Aqaba are relatively shallow) may play a role as the radiation varies greatly at shallow depths.<ref name=ieee/> In May, 2011, the President of the Jordanian Geologists Association Bahjat Al Adwan stated that the radiation is present in the water in the form of Radon, and thus dissipates harmlessly when the water is exposed to air on the surface.<ref name=JT5>{{cite news |last=Numan |first=Abeer |title=Disi water uncontaminated |url=http://www.jordantimes.com/index.php?news=37584 |accessdate=30 May 2011 |newspaper=The Jordan Times |date=18 May 2011}}</ref> This explanation has not been confirmed scientifically, however.<ref name=JT6>{{cite news |title=More reassurance needed |url=http://www.jordantimes.com/index.php?news=37618 |accessdate=30 May 2011 |newspaper=The Jordan Times |date=19 May 2011}}</ref>
During the inauguration of the conveyor in July 2013 Minister of Water and Irrigation Hazim El-Nasser said that after mixing Disi water radiation is less than 0.5 millisievert per year. The worldwide average natural dose of human's exposure to radiation is about 2.5-3 millisievert per year. "Disi water is purer than bottled water and I take full responsibility for what I’m saying,” the Minister said during a press conference.<ref name=Inauguration>Jordan Times:[http://jordantimes.com/king-inaugurates-disi-water-project King inaugurates Disi water project] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130719175728/http://jordantimes.com/king-inaugurates-disi-water-project |date=July 19, 2013 }}, 17 July 2013</ref>
==See also== *[[Red Sea–Dead Sea Water Conveyance]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Water supply and sanitation in Jordan]] [[Category:Infrastructure in Jordan]]

{{other uses}} [[File:Dog walking woman.jpg|thumb|A woman walking her dog]] [[Image:Dog walker - Buenos Aires.jpg|thumb|right|A dog walking service]] [[File:Walking from a dog's residence and then returning, in the Mission in San Francisco.ogv|thumb|thumbtime=5|A dog being walked]] '''Dog walking''' (colloquially '''walkies''') is the act of a person [[walking]] with a [[dog]], typically from the dog's residence and then returning. Both owners and pets receive many benefits.<ref>{{cite | url=https://m.petmd.com/dog/slideshows/general_health/top-ten-health-benefits-walking-your-pet-provides |title=Top Ten Benefits Walking Your Pet Provides| publisher=petmd.com | accessdate=8 June 2018}} </ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thisisgrimsby.co.uk/news/new-rules-woof-justice-pooches/article-2228828-detail/article.html|title=Are new rules woof justice for pooches?|date=29 May 2010|work=Grimsby Telegraph|publisher=thisisgrimsby.co.uk|accessdate=30 May 2010}}</ref> It also provides exercise and companionship for the walker.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://walking.about.com/od/dogwalking/a/dogwalking2006.htm|title=Dog Owners Get Twice as Much Exercise - Dog Walking for Exercise|last=Bumgardner|first=Wendy|date=13 November 2008|publisher=About.com|accessdate=30 May 2010}}</ref>
==Description== [[File:Free bags for dog walkers to pick up waste.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Many [[city|cities]] encourage dog walkers to pick up after their [[pet]]s by providing free baggies along popular paths or in [[park]]s, such as this one in [[Yorba Linda, California]].]]
In the UK, [[The Kennel Club]] conducted a survey of 1,000 dog owners and found that one in five did not walk their dogs on a daily basis.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1300658/Walkies-Fat-chance-One-dog-owners-lazy-pets-day.html?ito=feeds-newsxml|title=Walkies? Fat chance. One in five dog owners too lazy to take their pets out every day|last=Derbyshire|first=David|date=6 August 2010|work=[[Mail Online]]|accessdate=7 August 2010}}</ref>
Dogs are walked restrained by a [[Dog collar|collar]] around their neck or by a [[pet harness|harness]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.annarbor.com/pets/my-mantra-in-raising-and/|title=Commercialism: coming to a pet near you|last=Shaw|first=Lorrie|date=5 May 2010|publisher=AnnArbor.com|accessdate=30 May 2010}}</ref> or by simply following their guardian by familiarity and verbal control. Commonly, the dog is walked by the guardian, or by another family member, but there are also professional dog walkers.<ref name="lawyer"/>
==Health benefits== A study by [[Michigan State University]] showed that people who walk their dogs are 34% more likely to meet expected levels of exercise, with a recommended level of 150 minutes of activity such as dog walking per week. Matthew Reeves, the co-author of the study said, "There is no magic bullet in getting people to reach those benchmarks but walking a dog has a measurable impact."<ref name=notjust>{{cite news|title=Walkies Not Just For Dogs|url=http://www.express.co.uk/posts/view/234034/Walkies-not-just-for-dogs|newspaper=Daily Express|date=12 March 2011}}</ref>
Research conducted by the [[University of Western Australia]] has discovered that walking your dog helps build relationships in your community research showed that people in the community would acknowledge and greet other people in the street exchange favors with neighbors which can encourage more exercise in the community giving pets and owners a chance at a healthier life.
==Professional dog walkers== [[File:Dog walker on skates with six dogs cropped.jpg|thumb|right|This professional dog walker on skates is pulled rapidly down a street by six dogs in [[Summit, New Jersey]].]] Professional dog walkers, both individuals and businesses, are paid by dog owners to walk their dogs for them. Some dog walkers will take many dogs for a walk at once, while others will only take a single dog.<ref name="lawyer">{{cite news|url=http://news.scotsman.com/edinburgh/Lawyer-wants-to-bring-dog.6272446.jp|title=Lawyer wants to bring dog walkers to heel|last=Smith|first=Mark|date=5 May 2010|work=[[The Scotsman]]|accessdate=30 May 2010}}</ref> The length of a walk might vary by breed or owners request ranging from short relief walks to longer walks with a specific amount of time set by the owner. Also growing in popularity is "dog running". <ref>{{cite | url=https://www.runnersworld.com/runners-stories/a20864740/full-time-dog-runner/| title = Full-time Dog Runner | publisher=runnersworld.com| accessdate=8 June 2018}} </ref> Dog runners are professionals who run with dogs, rather than walking with them. In some jurisdictions, dog walking businesses must be licensed and have animal first-aid-trained employees. Professional dog walking services can be obtained locally or through online referral services. Obtaining a position as a professional dog walker has become more difficult, with applicants having to pass rigorous exams and go through extensive training.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/want-a-job-as-a-dog-walker-its-just-like-getting-into-harvard-1507214545|title=Want a Job as a Dog Walker? It’s Just Like Getting into Harvard|last=Higgins|first=Laine|date=2017-10-05|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-01-20|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}}</ref>
In the [[United States]], the first professional dog walker is believed to have been [[Jim Buck]], who in 1960 launched his dog walking service in [[New York City]].<ref name=margalit>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/13/nyregion/jim-buck-made-walking-dogs-a-job-dies-at-81.html?hp&_r=0 | title=Jim Buck, Who Made Walking Dogs a Job, Dies at 81 | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=12 July 2013 | accessdate=13 July 2013 | author=Fox, Margalit}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Pet sitting]] * [[Pet taxi]] * [[Dog daycare]]
==References==
{{reflist}}
==External links== * {{commons category inline|Dog walking}}
{{Domestic dog|state=collapsed}}

revision.text:
{{For|uses of E-Pro|E-Pro (disambiguation)}} An '''electronic patient-reported outcome''' ('''ePRO''') is a [[patient-reported outcome]] that is collected by electronic methods. ePRO methods are most commonly used in clinical trials, but they are also used elsewhere in health care. As a function of the regulatory process, a majority of ePRO questionnaires undergo the [[linguistic validation]] process.
==Methods== The two main methods currently used for ePRO are computers/Smartphones and telephone systems
''Computers'' are most often touch-screen devices, ranging from small hand-helds such as the Palm Pilot, through tablet PCs. The smaller devices are often used as electronic diaries, designed to be used for symptom reporting on a daily basis. Larger devices are generally used in a clinic setting. Computers generally run dedicated ePRO applications - the use of the web for ePRO is not yet widespread. Typically a single question at a time is presented on the screen, with a set of possible response options. The user taps on the appropriate response with finger or stylus, then moves on to the next questions.
''Telephones'' normally use an interactive voice response system ([[IVR]]). The user calls into a dedicated phone line, and hears a spoken script which details the question, and the possible responses. Each response option is given a number, and the user presses the corresponding number key on the phone keypad to record the choice. IVR systems are more often used for diaries, with the patient phoning in e.g. from home, but they can be used in a clinic setting.
There are also a number of custom devices designed specifically for use as ePRO data collection devices.
==Electronic diaries== Diaries are used when it is desirable to obtain frequent assessments over a period of time, for example when a condition fluctuates in severity. In such cases recall of severity over a period of time is unlikely to be accurate. Research has shown substantial bias in such summary recall, with ratings unduly influenced by how the patient is feeling at the time of making the rating, and by maximum severity rather than average severity during the assessment interval.<ref>{{Cite journal|vauthors=Stone AA, Broderick JE, Shiffman SS, Schwartz JE |title=Understanding recall of weekly pain from a momentary assessment perspective: absolute agreement, between- and within-person consistency, and judged change in weekly pain |journal=Pain|volume=107|issue=1-2 |pages=61–69 |year=2004 |pmid=14715390 |doi=10.1016/j.pain.2003.09.020}}</ref> Diaries can overcome this problem by recording severity either on a momentary basis ("How bad is your pain right now?") or by recall over short periods ("How bad has your pain been today?"). However, when diary data is collected on paper, it is not known when the ratings are actually made, and there is evidence that compliance may be quite poor. In one study, patients were given an instrumented paper diary that recorded covertly when it was opened. The study showed frequent cases of "back-filling", filling in a batch of entries some time, often days, after they were due, and even in some cases of "forward filling", completing entries before they were due.<ref>{{Cite journal|vauthors=Stone AA, Shiffman S, Schwartz JE, Broderick JE, Hufford MR |title=Patient non-compliance with paper diaries |journal=British Medical Journal |volume=324 |issue=7347 |pages=1193–1194 |date=2002-05-18 |pmid=12016186 |pmc=111114 |doi=10.1136/bmj.324.7347.1193}}</ref>
Electronic diaries automatically time-stamp all entries, and can be set up to only allow entry within specified time-windows. This improves compliance, and ensures that true compliance can be documented. Documenting compliance is important if ePRO data are to be used to support regulatory applications.<ref>http://www.fda.gov/downloads/Drugs/GuidanceComplianceRegulatoryInformation/Guidances/UCM193282.pdf</ref> ePRO applications typically achieve compliance rates of over 80%, often over 90%.<ref>{{Cite journal|vauthors=Meltzer EO, Kelley N, Hovell MF |title=Randomized, Cross-Over Evaluation of Mobile Phone vs Paper Diary in Subjects with Mild to Moderate Persistent Asthma |journal=Open Respir. Med. J. |volume=2 |pages=72–79 |year=2008 |pmid=19412327 |doi=10.2174/1874306400802010072 |pmc=2606655}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|vauthors=Friedberg F, Sohl SJ |title=Memory for Fatigue in Chronic Fatigue Syndrome: The Relation Between Weekly Recall and Momentary Ratings |journal=International Journal of Behavioral Medicine |volume=15 |issue=1 |pages=29–33 |year=2008 |pmid=18444018 |doi=10.1007/bf03003071}}</ref> Electronic diaries also have benefits in that they only allow valid, in-range entries to be made. Devices such as PDAs allow reminders to be given to patients when entries are due. Systems generally transfer data promptly to a central server, allowing tailored feedback to be given to patients. This can also improve compliance. Electronic diaries also eliminate the need for manual editing and entry of data, time-consuming and error-prone processes.
==Site-based== The other main setting for ePRO is the clinic, with questionnaires completed when patients come in for their scheduled visits. In this supervised situation, compliance is less of an issue. The questionnaires used in site-based ePRO are often longer and more complex than those used in diaries, assessing [[quality of life]] and activities of daily living, for example, in some detail. They more often include branching logic ("if YES continue with the next question, if NO, goto question 34"). Such branching logic can be handled automatically by the ePRO application, and it is often not necessary for the patient even to know that branching is taking place. This makes it easier for the patient to use.
As with electronic diaries, the prevention of out of range or inconsistent entries, and elimination of manual editing and data entry are important features of site-based ePRO. Missing data within a questionnaire can be reduced or eliminated, and this is important as missing data has been identified as a crucial quality issue in questionnaire data.<ref>{{Cite journal|vauthors=Bernhard J, Cella DF, Coates AS, Fallowfield L, Ganz PA, Moinpour CM, Mosconi P, Osoba D, Simes J, Hurny C |title=Missing quality of life data in cancer clinical trials: serious problems and challenges |journal=Statistics in Medicine |volume=17 |issue=5-7 |pages=517–532 |date=1998-03-15 |pmid=9549801 |doi=10.1002/(sici)1097-0258(19980315/15)17:5/7<517::aid-sim799>3.3.co;2-j}}</ref>
==Patient acceptability== From the early years of ePRO there has been concern about whether all patients can cope with computer technology. This is important,as if significant numbers of patients refuse to take part in clinical trials because of dislike of computers then there will be bias in the study population. One of the earliest ePRO studies used a LINC-2 minicomputer to collect patient data. The majority of patients preferred the computer to paper data collection.<ref>{{Cite journal|vauthors=Slack WV, Hicks GP, Reed CE, Van Cura LJ |title=A computer-based medical-history system |journal=New England Journal of Medicine |volume=274 |issue=4 |pages=194–198 |date=1966-01-27 |pmid=5902618 |doi=10.1056/NEJM196601272740406}}</ref> Similar findings have been reported from many later studies.<ref>{{Cite journal|vauthors=Crawley JA, Kleinman L, Dominitz J |title=User preferences for computer administration of quality of life instruments |journal=Drug Information Journal |volume=34 |pages=137–144 |year=2000 |doi=10.1177/009286150003400119}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|vauthors=Richter JG, Becker A, Koch T, Nixdorf M, Willers R, Monser R, Schacher B, Alten R, Specker C, Schneider M |title=Self-assessments of patients via Tablet PC in routine patient care: comparison with standardised paper questionnaires |journal=Annals of the Rheumatic Diseases |volume=67 |issue=12 |pages=1739–1741 |year=2008 |pmid=18647853 |doi=10.1136/ard.2008.090209}}</ref>
Elderly patients, and those not familiar with computers, might be expected to have more problems. But these groups also show high acceptance of ePRO, and again often prefer it to paper.<ref>{{Cite journal|vauthors=Yarnold PR, Stewart MJ, Stille FC, Martin GJ |title=Assessing functional status of elderly adults via microcomputer |journal=Percept.Mot.Skills |volume=82 |issue=2 |pages=689–690 |year=1996 |pmid=8724947 |doi=10.2466/pms.1996.82.2.689}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|vauthors=Allenby A, Matthews J, Beresford J, McLachlan SA |title=The application of computer touch-screen technology in screening for psychosocial distress in an ambulatory oncology setting |journal=European Journal of Cancer Care |volume=11 |issue=4 |pages=245–253 |year=2002 |pmid=12492461 |doi=10.1046/j.1365-2354.2002.00310.x}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|vauthors=Tiplady B, Goodman K, Cummings G, Lyle D, Carrington R, Battersby C, Ralston S |title=Patient Reported Outcomes in Rheumatoid Arthritis: Assessing the equivalence of electronic and paper data collection |journal=The Patient |volume=3 |issue=3 |pages=133–143 |year=2010 |doi=10.2165/11535590-000000000-00000}}</ref> Thus there seems to be no great barrier to recruiting representative patient samples in ePRO studies.
==Validity and equivalence== Establishing the validity of an ePRO instrument is in principle no different from that for other methods, such as paper. However most of the instruments in current use have been validated in paper form, and we need to ask (1) whether the paper data can be used to establish validity of the electronic version, and (2) whether data from paper and electronic versions can be used interchangeably.
The International Society for Pharmacoeconomomics and Outcomes Research (ISPOR) has issued guidelines on establishing equivalence between modes of administration.<ref>{{Cite journal|vauthors=Coons SJ, Gwaltney CJ, Hays RD, Lundy JJ, Sloan JA, Revicki DA, Lenderking WR, Cella D, Basch E |title=Recommendations on Evidence Needed to Support Measurement Equivalence between Electronic and Paper-based Patient-Reported Outcome (PRO) Measures: ISPOR ePRO Good Research Practices Task Force Report |journal=Value in Health |volume=12 |issue=4 |pages=419–429 |year=2009 |pmid=19900250 |doi=10.1111/j.1524-4733.2008.00470.x}}</ref> Their approach is hierarchical, and depends on the degree of change made during the process of migration from paper to electronic format. Three levels are suggested. At the lowest level, where least change has been made, cognitive interviewing of patients as a check that they construe ePRO and paper in the same way is sufficient. This level includes both trivial changes (touch rather than circle a response choice) as well as changes that are supported by empirical findings in the literature. At the second level, equivalence studies comparing the scores obtained from the two modes should be carried out. At the third level, where most change has occurred, the ePRO instrument must be treated as a new instrument, and complete psychometric validation carried out.
There is a great deal of evidence supporting the general equivalence of paper and ePRO methods. Gwaltney and colleagues<ref>{{Cite journal|vauthors=Gwaltney CJ, Shields AL, Shiffman S |title=Equivalence of Electronic and Paper-and-Pencil Administration of Patient-Reported Outcome Measures: A Meta-Analytic Review |journal=Value in Health |volume=11 |issue=2 |pages=322–333 |year=2008 |pmid=18380645 |doi=10.1111/j.1524-4733.2007.00231.x}}</ref> have reported a meta-analysis in which they included 46 studies evaluating 278 scales. They concluded that there was good agreement between paper and ePRO, and no evidence of systematic bias. This general finding, of course, does not guarantee that any specific migration will lead to equivalence, and each case must be reviewed and documented.
It is not always necessary to validate an ePRO measure against a pre-existing paper version. In some cases an instrument may be developed and validated from the beginning in electronic form. More commonly, perhaps, new instruments will be developed in parallel for paper and electronic use, as is the case with the PROMIS (Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System) initiative.<ref>{{Cite journal|author1=Fries, J. |author2=Cella, D. |author3=Rose, M. |author4=Krishnan, E. |author5=Bruce, B. |last-author-amp=yes |title=Progress in Assessing Physical Function in Arthritis: PROMIS Short Forms and Computerized Adaptive Testing |journal=The Journal of Rheumatology |volume=36 |issue=9 |pages=2061–2066 |year=2009 |pmid=19738214 |doi=10.3899/jrheum.090358}}</ref>
Standards of validity must be maintained throughout every target language population. In order to ensure that developmental standards are consistent in translated versions of an ePRO instrument, the translated instrument undergoes a process known as [[Linguistic validation]] in which the preliminary translation is adapted to reflect cultural and linguistic differences between diverse target populations. This process also accounts for any formatting errors that may occur in languages using non-Roman fonts.
==In practice== Several successful regulatory approvals have used ePRO data in recent years, including [[ketorolac]] for [[ocular]] pain, [[eszopiclone]] for [[insomnia]], [[milnacipran]] for [[fibromyalgia]], [[Estradiol (medication)|estradiol]]/[[levonorgestrel]] for [[post-menopausal]] symptoms, and [[ruxolitinib]] for [[myelofibrosis]].<ref>{{Cite journal|vauthors=McCallister E, Usdin S |title=A PROfessional Trial|journal=BioCentury, December 5th 2011 }}</ref> In the case of estradiol/levonorgestrel, detailed ePRO data on bleeding/spotting from a one-year clinical trial are presented in the patient information leaflet.<ref>http://dailymed.nlm.nih.gov/dailymed/drugInfo.cfm?id=10549#nlm34076-0</ref>
As well as clinical trial use, ePRO methods may be used to support patients in regular care. An example of this is the collection of symptom data from patients undergoing chemotherapy, using handheld diaries. This allows clinic staff to monitor outpatients, and to identify the occurrence of adverse reactions that may require intervention.<ref>{{Cite journal|author1=Kearney, N. |author2=McCann, L. |author3=Norrie, J. |author4=Taylor, L. |author5=Gray, P. |author6=Gee-Lennon, M. |author7=Sage, M. |author8=Miller, M. |author9=Maguire, R. |last-author-amp=yes|title=Evaluation of a mobile phone-based, advanced symptom management system (ASyMS-¬) in the management of chemotherapy-related toxicity |journal=Supportive Care in Cancer |volume=17 |issue=4 |pages=437–444 |date=2009-01-04 |pmid=18953579 |doi=10.1007/s00520-008-0515-0}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * Byrom B, Tiplady B (eds.) ''ePRO: Electronic Solutions for Patient-Reported Data'' (2010) Farnham: Gower. {{ISBN|978-0-566-08771-4}}. * Stone AA, Shiffman S, Atienza AA, Nebeling L (eds.) ''The Science of Real-Time Data Capture'' (2007) Oxford: Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|978-0-19-517871-5}}.
==External links== * [http://www.ispor.org/ International Society for Pharmacoeconomomics and Outcomes Research] * [http://www.nihpromis.org/default.aspx Patient-Reported Outcomes Measurement Information System ] * [http://cprohealth.org ''cPRO'', an open-source computerized PRO implementation] * [http://adaptest.com ''Adaptest<sup>TM</sup>'', a flexible, psychometric-based web-platform for the delivery of linear and adaptive PRO assessments]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Electronic Patient-Reported Outcome}} [[Category:Clinical trials]] [[Category:Clinical data management]] [[Category:Evaluation methods]] [[Category:Quality of life]]

revision.text:
[[File:Erika_Sutter_died_2015.jpg|thumb|right|Erika Sutter]] '''Erika Sutter''' (1917-2015) was a Swiss [[Ophthalmology|ophthalmologist]] and a medical missionary in [[South Africa]]. She became a lecturer at the International Centre for Eye Health (ICEH) and at the [[Swiss Tropical and Public Health Institute|Swiss Tropical Institute]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cartercenter.org/health/trachoma_education/manuals%20and%20technical%20resources/manuals%20full%20media%20to%20link%20p/15%20p.pdf |title=Book |website=cartercenter.org}}</ref> Motivated by her faith, she joined the Swiss Mission in South Africa and worked at the Elim Hospital. She made significant advances against [[malnutrition]] and [[trachoma]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|date=2015|title=Dr Erika Sutter 1917–2015|journal=Community Eye Health|volume=28|issue=91|pages=55|issn=0953-6833|pmc=4790168|pmid=26989318}}</ref> She practiced [[community mobilization]] and [[preventive healthcare]] through establishing a Care Group system. She wrote academic papers and books about her work. She was awarded an honorary doctorate degree by the [[University of Basel]], and the 1984 Woman of the Year.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YgzGqNhLY1UC&pg=PA206&lpg=PA206&dq=erika+sutter+south+africa&source=bl&ots=jp9F6wYVfb&sig=Id7TERqQsESwlaulkM_YWw_rxo8&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiH5r-07JvXAhXETCYKHSloCeEQ6AEIXzAP#v=onepage&q=erika%20sutter%20south%20africa&f=false|title=Women Marching Into the 21st Century: Wathint' Abafazi, Wathint' Imbokodo|date=2000|publisher=HSRC Press|isbn=9780796919663|language=en}}</ref>
== Early life ==
Erika Sutter was born in [[Basel]], [[Switzerland]] on June 14, 1917 to Ernst Theodor Sutter and Meta (née Ris). She had a sister Trudi. Her family had a second home in [[Troistorrents]]. She was homeschooled until third grade. From fourth grade, she enrolled in Basel girls' high school Gymnasium am Kohlenberg<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://ebookcentral.proquest.com/lib/upenn-ebooks/reader.action?docID=1986826|title=ProQuest Ebook Central|website=ebookcentral.proquest.com|language=en|access-date=2017-12-12}}</ref>. In 1937, Sutter enrolled in [[University of Basel]] and majored in [[botany]] and [[zoology]] along with minors in [[geography]] and [[physics]]. <ref name=":2" /> She continued studying after her undergraduate years and completed a [[doctorate]] in [[plant physiology]] in 1952.<ref name=":0" />. She worked at the Institute of Botany during her student years.
After considering a [[teacher|teaching]] career, she worked at Swiss pharmaceutical firm [[Hoffmann-La Roche]] in the [[Physiology|animal physiology]] department. In 1948, she worked in the botany department at the [[Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences]] in Ultana, where she stayed for two years.<ref name=":2" />
== Missionary career == Sutter first heard about the Swiss Mission in South Africa from her friend Marie-Louise Martin, who was then working as a [[Secondary school|high school]] [[chaplain]] in Basel. She contacted the [[Missionary|missionaries]] there to find out about the mission's work. Her plans were halted after the sudden deaths of her father and sister in 1945. Her interest in working for the Swiss Mission was reignited during her time in [[Sweden]]. Her encounters with missionaries there compelled her to pursue missionary work, and she left for South Africa in mid-April 1952.<ref name=":2" />
=== Motivations === Although raised a devout [[Christian]], Dr. Sutter did not see her commitment to missionary service as a [[religious calling]], nor a means to fulfill her personal ambition. She explains in her [[biography]] that it was “simply her path”.<ref name=":2" />
=== Achievements === From 1952 to 1984, Sutter worked at the Elim Hospital as a member of the staff and as an ophthalmologist for around twenty years. During that time, she was responsible for eye services and training of ophthalmic [[Nursing|nurses]] in the [[hospital]]. She worked mostly in the [[Limpopo|Northern Transvaal]] regions and was involved extensively in preventive health care in the community through the Care Groups.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://web.b.ebscohost.com/ehost/pdfviewer/pdfviewer?vid=2&sid=0145d1d9-003f-4d8d-aacf-2a9b71765c0c@sessionmgr104|title=Swiss Missionaries in South Africa.: EBSCOhost|website=web.b.ebscohost.com|language=en|access-date=2017-12-12}}</ref> To train to be an ophthalmologist, she returned to Switzerland to study ophthalmology and practice [[Surgery|surgical procedures]] in the Basel Eye Hospital. She returned to the Elim Hospital in 1965 as a certified ophthalmologist.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" /> As the only doctor in the eye department, she treated [[trachoma]] and various other eye diseases.<ref name=":2" /> However, as the eye hospital expanded and more doctors assisted in eye treatments, Sutter was able to direct her focus on achieving other visions.
Sutter had wanted to start a nursing school for eye care since she started working in South Africa, and in 1975, her dream was fulfilled when the South African Nursing Council officially recognized their new curriculum and approved the school. At the school, African nurses could be trained and receive an official [[diploma]] in ophthalmic nursing. That same year, she also established the Rivoni Society for the Blind, a rehabilitation center that offered workshops and training for the visually impaired and the blind. The society also offered a school for blind children where they could read [[Braille]] and learn how to use a [[typewriter]].<ref name=":2" />
=== Care Groups === In an effort to reduce cases of [[trachoma]], an eye disease that is easily curable with the application of good hygienic practices, Sutter helped organize Care Groups with Selina Maphorogo, her translator and main motivator of the Care Groups.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=http://www.medicusmundi.ch/de/bulletin/mms-bulletin/frauengesundheit/frauenspezifische-gesundheitsarbeit-von-fragestellungen-zu-programmen/community-development-and-women2019s-self-reliance-in-south-africa|title=Community development and women’s self-reliance in South Africa|work=Medicus Mundi Schweiz|access-date=2017-12-12|language=de-CH}}</ref> Care Groups aimed to mobilize local people, mostly women, to spread awareness to local communities about trachoma and how to prevent it.<ref name=":2" /> As a result of their efforts, the number of active trachoma cases was reduced by 50% within three years.<ref name=":0" /> Care Groups have helped spread awareness and address a wide range of problems such as [[HIV/AIDS]] and [[malnutrition]] in the region.<ref name=":2" /> The project quickly multiplied; by 2002, 10,000 women were working in 300 villages.<ref name=":4" />
== Works == One of Sutter’s most significant publications is ''Hanyane, a Village Struggles for Eye Health,'' an educational book that has been translated into many languages.<ref name=":3" /> The book goes into detail about effective [[Preventive healthcare|preventive care]] and village development, and documents useful medical notes for ophthalmologists.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Hanyane: A Village Struggles for Eye Health|last=Sutter|first=Erika|publisher=International Centre for Eye Health|year=1989|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref>
Her work ''The Community is my University is'' a compilation of interviews with her and Selina Maphorogo. This book mainly focused on Care Groups and [[development aid]].<ref name=":3" />
== Recognition ==
* Woman of the Year in 1984.<ref name=":1" /> * Honorary doctorate degree from the University of Basel for her work and accomplishments in South Africa in 1995. * Trachoma Gold Medal awarded by the French ''Ligue Internationale Contre le Trachome'' (1996). * Ophthalmological Society of South Africa (2005). [[Mamphela Ramphele]], a South African politician and an activist against [[apartheid]], praised Erika as a “fellow global citizen, [who] not only opened the physical eyes of those she encountered but also their spiritual eyes, to appreciate the power they had within them.” <ref name=":3" />
== Retirement == Sutter retired in 1984 at 67 and returned to Basel, Switzerland. In her retirement, she spent most of her time traveling and giving presentations and teaching at the Swiss Tropical Institute in Basel and at the International Centre for Eye Health in England.<ref name=":2" /> Dr. Erika Sutter died in 2015 at age 98.<ref name=":0" />
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Sutter, Erika}} [[Category:1917 births]] [[Category:Women ophthalmologists]] [[Category:Medical missionaries]] [[Category:2015 deaths]] [[Category:Missionaries]]
